text.text: You should look at this chart about music genres.
In 2016, Spotify began publishing a chart of popular genres on its platform.
Let’s now fast forward six years later and see how the ranking has changed.
I’ve highlighted the genres that are not among the top 25 in 2016. I wondered why so many genres shifted in popularity.
This led me down a rabbit hole to explore Spotify’s database of 6,000 genres, and it’s changed the way that I think about music.
So pull up a chair for a great dinner table discussion about genre. Before we launch into a philosophical debate about music, let’s start with something for casual music fans.
In 2023, nearly half of the top 25 genres hail from Latin America, Africa, and Asia.
Today, Spotify users from North America and Europe represent a much smaller share of streams than in 2016.
Every year, Spotify is available in more countries. Spotify was made available in South Korea in 2021. And India in 2019. Fittingly, you can see non-English genres begin to dominate in popularity.
So many non-English genres have ascended in popularity: k-pop is, by far, the biggest gainer since 2016. Over the past 7 years, it’s ascended to the 19th most-streamed genre.
K-pop now has more streams than r&b and edm.
You’ve probably heard of Bad Bunny, the world’s most-streamed musician, three years running. Fittingly, reggaeton is the only other genre to exhibit a k-pop-like ascent.
Does k-pop just feel popular because streaming is more global? Is reggaeton pervasive because we’re finally counting the true popularity of English-centric artists?
Next, let’s discuss the remaining 5,975 genres in Spotify’s dataset. Music nerds, pull up a chair.
This dataset represents an ocean of of genres that represent an ongoing attempt to catalogue every music community.
